section.name: Introduction
section.p: A frequent question we get is "how do I test my javascript?". It really isn't very different from testing the page itself so lets walk through some examples.

section.name: Example: using Document.write()
section.p: Lets say that we have a page containing javascript that will dynamically write content to the page. The following html will dynamically generate five textfields and place them inside a table. Each textfield will have a unique name created by appending the index to the string "textfield".
We would likely want to test that the five text fields were created so we could start with this.

We might also want to check off-by-one errors by ensuring that it didn't create "textfield0" or "textfield6". Trying to get an element that doesn't exist will cause an exception to be thrown so we could add this to the end of the previous test.

section.name: Example: Watching for 'alerts'
section.p: Often you want to watch alerts triggered by javascript.

Alerts are tracked by an AlertHandler which will be called whenever the javascript alert() function is called. In the following test, we register an alert handler which just saves all messages into a list. When the page load is complete, we compare that list of collected alerts with another list of expected alerts to ensure they are the same.

section.name: Prompts, Confirms and Status line messages
section.p: Handling prompt dialogs, confirm dialogs and status line messages work in the same way as alerts. You register a handler of the appropriate type and it will get notified when that method is called. See WebClient.setPromptHandler(), WebClient.setConfirmHandler() and WebClient.setStatusHandler() for details on these.

section.name: Event handlers
section.p: Some event handlers are already implemented and will be triggered at the appropriate time (see table below).

If the event that you wish to test is not yet supported then you can directly invoke it through the ScriptEngine. Note that while the script engine is publicly accessible, we do not recommend using it directly unless you have no other choice. It is much better to manipulate the page as a user would by clicking on elements and shifting the focus around.

tr.td: "onload" handlers on body or frameset elements will be triggered after the page has been loaded but before it is returned to the caller.
This will be triggered when the click() method of a ClickableElement is called.
The method WebClient.moveFocusToElement(...) will change the focus to the appropriate element. This event will be triggered when an element gets focus.
The method WebClient.moveFocusToElement(...) will change the focus to the appropriate element. This event will be triggered when an element loses focus.
This will be triggered when a form is submitted using a control on the form.
This will be triggered when a form is reset either by HtmlForm.reset() or via the javascript reset() method.
This will be triggered when the appropriate setValueAttribute() method is called.
